(Zonule of Zinn visible near center.) | System = | MeshName = | MeshNumber = | DorlandsPre = z_01 | DorlandsSuf = 12870397 | }} The '''zonule of Zinn''' ('''Zinn's membrane''', '''ciliary zonule''') (after [[Johann Gottfried Zinn]]) is a ring of fibrous strands connecting the [[ciliary body]] with the crystalline [[lens (anatomy)|lens]] of the [[human eye|eye]]. ==Development== The ciliary epithelial cells of the eye probably synthesize portions of the zonules.<ref name=AdlersPhysiology>{{cite book|last=Kaufman|first=Paul L.|title=Adler's physiology of the eye|year=2010|publisher=Mosby|location=St. Louis, Mo|isbn=978-0-323-05714-1|pages=145–146|edition=11th ed.|coauthors=Alm, Albert}}</ref> ==Anatomy== The zonule of Zinn is split into two layers: a thin layer, which lines the [[hyaloid fossa]], and a thicker layer, which is a collection of zonular fibers. Together, the fibers are known as the suspensory ligament of the lens.<ref>http://www.etsu.edu/cpah/hsci/forsman/WebVision.htm</ref> The zonules are about 1–2 μ in diameter.<ref name=ScannningEM>{{cite journal|last=Bornfeld|first=Norbert|coauthors=Spitznas, Manfred; Breipohl, Winrich; Bijvank, Gerhard J.|title=Scanning electron microscopy of the zonule of Zinn|journal=Albrecht von Graefes Archiv for Klinische und Experimentelle Ophthalmologie|year=1974|volume=192|issue=2|pages=117–129|doi=10.1007/BF00410698|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> When colour granules are displaced from the Zonules of Zinn (by friction against the lens), the irises slowly fade. In some cases those colour granules clog the channels and lead to [[Glaucoma]] Pigmentosa. The zonules are primary made of [[fibrillin]], a connective tissue protein.<ref name=AdlersPhysiology /> Mutations in the fibrillin gene lead to the condition Marfans Syndrome, and consequences include an increased risk of lens dislocation.<ref name=AdlersPhysiology /> ==Clinical appearance== The zonules of Zinn are difficult to visualize using a slit lamp, but may be seen with exceptional dilation of the pupil, or if a [[coloboma]] of the iris or a [[Lens subluxation|suluxation of the lens]] is present.<ref>{{cite journal|last=McCulloch|first=C|title=The Zonule of Zinn: its Origin, Course, and Insertion, and its Relation to Neighboring Structures.|journal=Transactions of the American Ophthalmological Society|year=1954-1955|volume=52|pages=525–85|pmid=13274438|url=http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1312608/pdf/taos00047-0532.pdf|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> The number of zonules present in a person appears to decrease with age.<ref name=ScannningEM /> The zonules insert around the outer margin of the lens (equator), both anteriorly and posteriorly.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Farnsworth|first=PN|coauthors=Mauriello, JA; Burke-Gadomski, P; Kulyk, T; Cinotti, AA|title=Surface ultrastructure of the human lens capsule and zonular attachments.|journal=Investigative ophthalmology|date=1976 Jan|volume=15|issue=1|pages=36–40|pmid=1245377|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> ==Additional Images== <gallery> File:Three Main Layers of the Eye.png|Structures of the eye labeled File:Three Internal chambers of the Eye.png|This image shows another labeled view of the structures of the eye </gallery> ==References== <references/> ==External links== * [http://www.unmc.edu/Physiology/Mann/pix_7/ciliary.gif Diagram at unmc.edu] * [http://www.eye-surgery-uk.com/images/sk_glau.gif Diagram at eye-surgery-uk.com] * [http://webschoolsolutions.com/patts/systems/eye.htm Diagram and overview at webschoolsolutions.com] * {{eMedicineDictionary|ciliary+zonule}} * {{BUHistology|08011loa}} {{Gray's}} {{Eye}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zonule Of Zinn}} [[Category:Human eye anatomy]] [[Category:Ligaments]]
